content:
Hey everyone, totally random question.

So, due to inspiration from @Boxy and @Jane Lusby, I am creating areweyeetyet.rs (not up yet). I am trying to add a small timeline of events on the page, anyone know the origins of the idea / want to help add some key events?
There was also some discussion on IRLO recently
Also, I think the "we" in the title should be capitalized.
Loool
Beautiful
I can try to dig up the timeline, I think the gist is some of my friends memed about this in discord and then I tweeted about it offhand one day and then @Josh Triplett ran with it

https://twitter.com/ManishEarth/status/1247538742602031107?s=19

@yaahc_ THIEF

- Manish (@ManishEarth)
Yea so manish came up with it
Got it, thanks!
This is when later came up in an edition planning meeting that I made a tweet summary thread about

https://twitter.com/yaahc_/status/1252383870986534915?s=19

# Early return with error looking to reserve a keyword with this, YEET IS A STRONG CONTENDER AND GOT MENTIONED IN THE MEETING (as a joke) reserving a keyword is dependent upon them resolving the bikeshed to pick one, which hasn't even started yet tho, soooo

- Yaah ü¶Ä (@yaahc_)
Here's the earlier even where josh got super excited

https://twitter.com/josh_triplett/status/1248658754976927750?s=19

@yaahc_ @rustlang You've also inspired a new placeholder to facilitate discussion. For early-exit-with-error syntax, instead of saying "fail, raise, throw, etc", I'm going to just write `yeet err;` as a neutral placeholder. Thanks!

- Josh Triplett (@josh_triplett)
Aah, apparently it wasn't a tweet, it was my symme(try) blog post

https://twitter.com/yaahc_/status/1248648763855396867?s=19

I wrote a short blog post about the differences between Ok-wrapping, function level try, try blocks, and how try could be generalized to other kinds of blocks. cc @rustlang https://yaah.dev/try-blocks

- Yaah ü¶Ä (@yaahc_)
Looks good. I will add those and send a message here when I push (source is https://github.com/jakevossen5/areweyeetyet.rs)
One more thing

From my perspective the yeet thing last ended here https://twitter.com/yaahc_/status/1359886855013994501?s=19

Should I unironically try to get "yeet" reserved as a keyword for rust 2021 edition? Note: this involves real work that I'd have to do this month

- Yaah ü¶Ä (@yaahc_)
When I briefly considered reserving it as a keyword
But was convinced that I shouldn't because yeet is for the people
And reserving it as a keyword would disallow using it as an identifier
Which would be detrimental to us all
At least so goes the argument, I'm guessing that you still want yeet :sweat_smile:
"yeet is for the people" oh my god I'm dying this is phenomenal
I like ‚Äúyeet is for the people‚Äù lol. I don‚Äôt think yeet is a bad keyword for what is being described, and I feel like the story needs to be documented anyways

And the tweets came at a good time, because the language team had just been talking about what keyword to use, which was a matter of much debate. And it felt uncomfortable always either enumerating a pile of potential keywords or picking one that the speaker preferred.

Jane Lusby said:

But was convinced that I shouldn't because yeet is for the people

Cast off your yokes, up with the yotes!
The yoting public demands it.
"Alright, which keyword is it going to be, check your boxes below to cast your yotes"
Or, after an especially 'good' bikeshedding session: "Well, that produced more yeet than light."
omg

@Jake Vossen FWIW, I think you'd get even more attention drawn to that page if you (unironically) give some background on the problem yeet is trying to solve, talk about other potential keywords, link to some of the issues tracking the introduction of the language construct, and in general become the canonical place to look for information on whether throw/fail/yeet is a thing yet. Complete with pervasive humor that of course yeet is the right choice. ;)

We're 24 hours away from having an accepted RFC mention yeet (non-normatively).

(I remember some comment from I thought josh on I thought reddit about yeet definitely not going to be the final keyword, but I can't find it again. And I guess it'd be off-brand for the page anyway.)
Josh would never say such a thing
@scottmcm (Yeah, I've made comments to that effect before.)
:mad:
top 10 anime betrayals moment

FWIW, completely unironically, I'd absolutely accept a PR implementing yeet (or perhaps k#yeet with the new keyword reservation mechanism), so that people can start trying it out while we're figuring out what keyword it should use.
I think it's the perfect keyword to prototype that with.
is the keyword reservation stuff already implemented?
If you're looking for more context, @Jake Vossen, you might add boats's https://without.boats/blog/why-ok-wrapping/ to the page.
It's not even an accepted RFC yet.
ah okay
Not even in FCP any more.
darn
@scottmcm Yeah, I'm thinking we should perhaps scale it back and drop the foo"string" bits so that we can get k#keyword in.
That said, there's always the classic "well it's do yeet for now" approach.
(petition to accept ya as a synonym for do...)

Josh Triplett said:

scottmcm Yeah, I'm thinking we should perhaps scale it back and drop the foo"string" bits so that we can get k#keyword in.

Seems that'd be practical, yeah. Can always get strings in next edition :P
ya ah
ya ah c, you might say :smirk:
lol

And the semantic idea of yeet e goes back all the way to 2014 and https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/blob/master/text/0243-trait-based-exception-handling.md#throw-and-throws -- though that wasn't enlightened enough to use yeet yet.
The keyword reservation mechanism has many other humorous possibilities. There could be a whole keyword namespace for writing Ruwust, for maximum k#yuteness.
Frankly, as a non-english speaker i have totally no idea what does yeet mean or how to pronounce it... lol
"Yeet - To discard an item at a high velocity" - urban dictionary
"discard" is not nearly strong enough, yeet is like /r/thecatdimension level of speed
ok yes here is a good example watch the cat http://i.chzbgr.com/maxW500/8243956992/h7F5750FF.gif
that cat yeets out of there
and you pronounce it like "wheat" but with a y

Charles Lew said:

Frankly, as a non-english speaker i have totally no idea what does yeet mean or how to pronounce it... lol

Frankly, as a native english speaker, I had never heard of the word until it showed up in this context.
@scottmcm this is a clear sign you're not keeping up with the latest memes, a sure sign of moral failing
:older_man:
literally https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yjLs8wAXoOE
only this is "The Yeet Zone"
Sorry I was offline for a bit (spontaneous Catan game) thanks everyone for the advice and background!
this was a delightful thread to wake up to lmao

Having spent some time with my kids explaining that slang terms are inappropriate jargon for the professional or academic workplace, and belaboring the point that the word "throw" already exists and encapsulates essentially the same meaning (hence negating the very necessity of its existence!), I find myself thinking that yeet is a four letter word, and a more efficient keyword than throw. Have I lost my mind?

I always find it funny that we have Ok in the std. I had it drilled into me for years, that it was insolent to use that slang spelling. The word is spelled "Okay", spelling it as "Ok" is just a way to make fun of your teachers for claiming that "you can sound out words". I don't want to know how many times I have bean publicly corrected for that. So, what is slang is entirely context depended. What is inappropriate forms of speech/spelling is entirely context depended. Who decides what is slang and inappropriate is entirely a political question. ( Thanks for coming to my ted talk. )
OK is a loan word that has been Americanized as "Okay". No one really knows for certain where it came from
Alright everyone, first version of https://areweyeetyet.rs is up
